DOCNAME: DESTILACIJA PLC v. BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA
JUDGES: Lech Garlicki;Ledi Bianku;Nicolas Bratza;Päivi Hirvelä;Sverre Erik Jebens;Vincent A. De Gaetano
TEXT: The applicant is a private company with headquarters in LOC , GPE . It was represented before the ORG by Mr PERSON and Mr PERSON , lawyers practising in PERSON . ORG GPE ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Deputy Agent , PERSON .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

The applicant company had a right of allocation with respect to a flat in LOC ( as explained below , the allocation right holders were socially owned enterprises and other public bodies which administered socially owned flats in the former ORG ) . On DATE it initiated administrative proceedings for the eviction of ORG who had remained in the flat after the death of his grandfather .

On DATE the competent first - instance administrative body ruled that the occupancy right over the flat could not be transferred to ORG from his late grandfather and , accordingly , ordered his eviction . On DATE and CARDINAL DATE , respectively , the competent second - instance administrative body and ORG of ORG upheld that decision . PERSON was evicted on DATE .

On DATE PERSON complained to ORG , a domestic human - rights body , about the outcome of the administrative proceedings mentioned above , relying on Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of , and LAW No . CARDINAL to , LAW .

On DATE ORG ( the legal successor of ORG ) found a violation of GPE ’s right to respect for his home , quashed the ORG decision of DATE and ordered that he be reinstated in the flat . The applicant company was informed of that decision through the housing authorities on CARDINAL DATE .
On DATE ORG , pursuant to the ORG decision , quashed the decisions of DATE and DATE and ruled against the applicant company .
It would appear that the applicant company has subsequently agreed to the privatisation of the flat by ORG under LAW ( see below ) .

In the former ORG practically all flats were under the regime of “ social ownership ” . They were generally built by socially owned enterprises or other public bodies for allocation to their employees , who became “ occupancy right holders ” . The rights of both the allocation right holders ( public bodies which nominally controlled the flats ) and the occupancy right holders were regulated by law ( LAW DATE , which is still in force in GPE ) .

In accordance with this LAW , an occupancy right , once allocated , entitled the occupancy right holder to permanent , lifelong use of the flat against the payment of a nominal fee . When occupancy right holders died , their rights transferred , as a matter of right , to their surviving spouses or registered members of their family households who were also using the flat ( see sections DATE and CARDINAL of that Act ) . In practice , these provisions on transfer meant that occupancy rights originally allocated by public bodies to their employees could pass , as of right , to multiple generations for whom the initial employment - based link to the allocation right holder no longer existed ( for more information about socially owned flats see PERSON GPE , no . CARDINAL/CARDINAL , § § CARDINAL - CARDINAL , DATE ) .

The concept of “ social ownership ” was abandoned during the DATE - CARDINAL war . As a result , socially owned flats were effectively nationalised . Under LAW , which entered into force on DATE , the occupancy right holders were entitled to purchase their flats . Furthermore , the role of the allocation right holders changed . They are now obliged to agree to the privatisation of flats if the occupancy right holder so requests ( see section CARDINAL of that Act ) , or , in the absence of such a request , to let out the flat ( section CARDINAL ) of that Act ) . In both cases , the proceeds ( that is , the purchase price or the rent ) are to be paid to ORG ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) of that Act ) .
